Let's start with the strong parts: the cast is great, the actors carry what is otherwise a pretty average movie that lacks bite in its final act. The visual effects are pretty great as are the vistas surrounding the titular gorge (filmed in Norway). The bad: plot is predictable and not without plot holes large enough to drive a jeep into - e.g. the petrol in any of the ww2 vehicles present in the gorge would long have evaporated by the time the events of the movie take place), jump scares aren't that scary (though YMMV - my skittish other half kept jumping whenever the obviously telegraphed monsters appeared) and, given this is meant to be a horror flic, it lacks bite. !Spoiler alert! The movie telegraphs that a weapon developped during WW2 got released during an earthquake causing humans and animals to mutate into part-plant (sometimes part bug) monstrosities with a 5 day time window being telegraphed for mutation to start showing. Both characters are in the fog causing this mutation, and even remark how they need to quarantine themselves afterwards to make sure they are mutation-free. Somewhat disappointingly, both manage to make it to the end of the story entirely untouched by their time in the gorge.

The Gorge is a gripping cinematic experience that masterfully combines heart-pounding action, deep emotion, and surprising tenderness. It hooks you from the opening scene and never lets up. The narrative fearlessly explores trauma, connection, and redemption, paired with stunning visuals and a haunting soundtrack. The cast delivers authentic, compelling performances, grounding even the wildest moments. The direction strikes a perfect balance between thrilling sequences and poignant, introspective moments, giving the film remarkable depth. It’s both exhilarating and profound, appealing to fans of suspense, rich characters, or fresh storytelling. The Gorge lingers long after the credits. My partner and I loved it, chuckling at the quirky romance blossoming amidst the chaos of a hellish battlefield.

Review: The Gorge Rating: ★★★★★ The Gorge is a cinematic thrill ride that blends intense action, raw emotion, and unexpected heart. From the very first scene, it grabs your attention and doesn’t let go. The storytelling is bold and unafraid to dig into the complexities of trauma, connection, and redemption, all while delivering jaw-dropping visuals and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. The performances are standout—each character feels grounded and real, even in the most surreal moments. The direction is tight, with a perfect balance between high-stakes sequences and quieter, emotional beats that give the film real depth. It’s a rare gem that manages to be both exhilarating and meaningful. Whether you're into edge-of-your-seat suspense, layered characters, or simply want to be moved by something original, The Gorge is absolutely worth the watch. It stays with you long after the credits roll. This was truly a favorite of my partner and I. We laughed at the characters and the silliness behind falling in love on the literal front lines of hell.

(NO SPOILERS) "The Gorge" really took me by surprise. I wasn’t expecting much — just one trailer, a colleague's offhand comment that it’s a decent B-movie — but I ended up getting way more than I bargained for. It’s kind of straddling the line between an A and a B production, but in terms of story, it's genuinely interesting and refreshingly original (from what I gather, it’s not based on anything). The movie kicks off right away by introducing the two leads — Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy — and pretty quickly things get intriguing. At first, it’s just the two of them guarding some mysterious gorge, communicating via paper notes through a telescope. But then the plot evolves into an action-packed sci-fi filled with monsters, secrets, and unexpected twists. The atmosphere is spot-on, the score fits perfectly, and the action is fun and at times genuinely suspenseful. Stylistically, it feels like a more polished genre piece, but what really elevates it is the chemistry between the leads. Teller is solid, but Anya Taylor-Joy absolutely owns this movie. Okay, I’ll admit I’ve got a soft spot for her, and with the short dark hair in this role, she was just irresistible — sexy and magnetic. Every scene she’s in was instantly more enjoyable, and I won’t lie, that probably bumped up my score a bit. But bias aside, this is a clever mix of romance, sci-fi, and action, set in an original world that dares to step outside the usual genre boundaries. No, it’s not a groundbreaking masterpiece, but it’s got charm, style, and a story that keeps you watching. Definitely recommended for a cozy movie night — ideally with wine, popcorn, and good vibes. |7/10|

More often than not, genre and tone mixing distracts from a film’s story, but interestingly enough – may it be due to the star power and chemistry of both leads, or the direction of Scott Derickson – The Gorge mixes traditional romcom with B-movie sci-fi horror to an enjoyable outcome. Levi (Teller) and Drasa (Taylor-Joy) are two elite snipers receiving an identical mission, guarding opposite sides of a remote, top-secret gorge for one year with no contact with each other and the outside world. Levi’s predecessor explains that the perimeters are armed with sentries to contain creatures within the gorge, nicknamed “The Hollow Men”. His predecessor is then killed by their employer, alluding to a darker secret. Months later, Drasa violates the no-communication protocol by writing signs, having a sharpshooting contest and playing loud music. Hollow Men attempted to climb out of the gorge utilizing this distraction but the couple managed to defend their respective boundaries. Their bond grew, leading to Levi finding a way to zipline across the gorge to spend a romantic night with Drasa, however the next morning Levi accidentally falls down the Gorge as the creatures attacked again. Drasa consequently parachutes after him. We then follow the pair as they struggle to survive a hellish landscape filled with monsters, on top of discovering the gorge’s secret; a failed bioweapons lab abandoned after a containment leak. All maintained by their employers in order to extract samples and make super soldiers. Most of the plot warrants suspension of disbelief, thesurvival of both leads in an area filled with monsters is B-movie and video-gamecoded. Predictable, but enjoyable due to its charismatic leads, it proved itsworth as a tv movie amongst its contemporaries but it’s not something worthwatching on the big screen.

We watched the Gorge, a scifi suspense movie about two special sniper opps played by Anya Taylor and Miles Teller, from Whiplash & Top Gun. Thinking this was going to be a less intricate plot and more of a let’s see where this goes premise, I was actually pleasantly surprised with the depth of the relationship and sci-fi fantasy development of the film, making it less of a dry stoic thriller. I anticipated a whole silent tense suspense thriller using minimal dialogue and a lot of reserved acting that would only let up toward the last 3rd of the film but it was full of life from the first interaction between them. I wished Id watched it in theaters for the heightened tension. It would have been worth it as one of the few movies that came out this year. Now on the creative sci-fi horror direction, wow that wasn’t stale, it was juicy with dark designs and eeriness and tech. Being a more stylish artistic and metaphorical hell was a good choice as the unfeeling meaningless bio-horror that has been over done in modern films, and it brought it back to a 90s imaginative Del-Toro, Event Horizon type of interpretation which brought elements of “evil” playing a part into the scifi in a way that was intriguing and not corny. The sound design was also a plus, the intimate quiet buildup and the eerie pulsating techno music really pulled me in like older horror scifi that give you a sense of dread and exoticness. I miss esoteric scifi concepts and visions that used to spark my imagination, and this kinda satisfied that litch without being too bizarre. The best part that carried the movie was the performance and chemistry of the two actors with their quick-reactions, daring decisions and vulnerable performance. They never disappoint in both of their specialities- his being a witty, driven, mtraumatized, enduring, upcoming military opps, and Anya being a spunky coy petite talented European girl who always is willing to go for the kill to defend herself and others.

Entertaining Action for Valentine’s Day As a movie released for Valentine’s Day, it works really well. If you’re tired of the usual romance films, this is the perfect excuse to fill the love-movie slot you have to watch with your partner that day—without feeling like a sacrifice. The most interesting thing about this sci-fi movie with action, mystery, creatures, and romance is that, without a doubt, the best part is the romance itself. Beyond that, the production value is quite impressive, with action scenes and special effects that far exceed what you’d expect from a film like this. However, the real highlight—the factor that makes the movie enjoyable—is the lead couple. Miles Teller delivers a solid performance, while Anya Taylor-Joy once again brings that extra spark she always seems to have. Overall, it’s a decent film. Don’t expect anything extraordinary, but as a Valentine’s Day alternative, it shouldn’t disappoint.

HOLY F***ING SH*T!! What a movie! What an ending! This film is an absolute rollercoaster of mystery, suspense, and adventure. It’s the kind of movie we’ve all been craving for so long, a perfect blend of thrills and surprises. And oh my God, the jump scares? Perfectly timed, heart-stopping, and utterly terrifying. Every scene felt like a punch to the gut in the best way possible. The characters were compelling, the visuals stunning, and the soundtrack amplified every moment of tension. I would watch this in theaters again and again without ever getting tired of it. An absolute must-see for anyone who loves edge-of-your-seat storytelling and unforgettable cinematic experiences!

The Gorge is the latest film from Apple studios and it’s is a fun, wild, but often uneven film. The movie starts off very mysterious building up a little backstory for our two main leads that is somewhat generic. The backstory of our main heroes is not what you came to see from this film. You came to see a lot of action and see what wild things are in the gorge. I will say I was pretty surprised by the creativity and crazy elements that we get to witness halfway through this film. I will not spoil anything here for you. The movie keeps you interested the whole time but however has a cliche type of ending. The Gorge gets a solid 3 1/2 stars out of 5.

The Gorge is a cool but forgettable film. Frankly I hoped for a little bit better than a generic sci-fi horror from Scott Derrickson. It did took me by surprise with its ever-shifting nature, evolving from a romantic two-hander involving two elite snipers into a sci-fi action horror blockbuster. Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy anchor the film with compelling performances and great chemistry, while Dan Laustsen’s gorgeous cinematography and Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross’s score elevate it past some of its narrative pitfalls. While it begins to feel aimless by the halfway mark, the action ramps up and attempts to distract from its overall lack of depth. It’s just unfortunate that the initial intrigue gets pushed to the back burner by the end, though the time we spend with our leads is charming enough. It hits its mark, just not always with pinpoint precision.

My husband and I recently watched "The Gorge" on Apple TV+, and it was an exhilarating experience from start to finish. Directed by Scott Derrickson, this film masterfully blends science fiction, romance, and action, creating a unique narrative that kept us on the edge of our seats. The story follows two elite snipers, Levi Kane (Miles Teller) and Drasa (Anya Taylor-Joy), tasked with guarding a mysterious gorge. As they uncover the gorge's dark secrets, including monstrous creatures and the remnants of a bioweapons research lab, the film delves into themes of love, sacrifice, and redemption. The chemistry between Teller and Taylor-Joy is palpable, bringing depth to their characters' evolving relationship. Sigourney Weaver's presence adds a layer of gravitas, enriching the film's narrative. One of the standout elements of "The Gorge" is its impeccable soundtrack. The music perfectly complements the film's intense action sequences and tender, romantic moments with an edge. The rock-infused score adds a very edgy, cool, and eccentric vibe to the film, amplifying the atmosphere and enhancing emotional depth and tension at just the right moments. Whether it's the haunting melodies during suspenseful scenes or the edgy rock tunes accompanying heartfelt exchanges, the soundtrack is an essential part of the film's storytelling. Visually, the film is stunning, with breathtaking landscapes and intense action sequences that are both thrilling and beautifully choreographed. The storyline kept us engaged with its unexpected twists and emotional depth, culminating in a satisfying and heartfelt conclusion. While the film's ambitious mix of genres might not be for everyone, we found it to be a captivating and well-executed cinematic experience. Whether you're a fan of science fiction, romance, or action, "The Gorge" offers something for everyone. Overall, "The Gorge" is a thrilling and heartfelt journey, elevated by its perfect soundtrack and the tender, romantic moments that carry an edge, making it a film that you will watch again. The Gorge is an visually striking action thriller with an great unique concept and a great cast. While it starts off a bit slow, once it picks up it's very interesting, the chemistry between the leads are one of the film's biggest strengths. The action is pretty solid, with good special effects especially on the monster designs. The cinematography is really immersive, adding to the film's overall vibe, and the soundtrack is a bop. It really feels like this film should have been in cinema/theatres instead of straight to streaming it really deserved the big screen treatment. The second act is where the movie truly shines, keeping the tension and excitement high. However, the third act, while still engaging, unfortunately loses a bit of the momentum and didn't hold my interest as much as the middle of the film. It's a close call between a 4 and a 3.5, but ultimately, 3.5/5 felt right.

The Gorge is a brilliant concept with multiple roles and multiple parts. On the one hand, we have two of our protagonists kindling love from a distance, and on the other, “the gorge” that keeps them apart. Essentially, what seems to be a simple plot, is architecturally a psychological one, as both characters are insinuated to keep their eyes upon one another for the dangers that lurk beneath. Zach Dean’s writing for the film was a multi-faceted one, comprising multiple acts, and story arcs to be fulfilled. Building an entire world and its mythology for audiences to see. Neglecting that it could take from, what was instantaneously, a simply marvel concept to begin with. Scott Derrickson’s direction does little to no mitigation to the script, condensing the film down to a two-hour film that meddles in its beginnings only to run to its finish. Miles Teller & Anya Taylor Joy both salvage this film with their notably convincing charm, able to draw human moments from what would otherwise be unrelatable subjects to a film.

**Review of *The Gorge* (★★★☆☆)** I had high hopes for *The Gorge*, and while it delivers in some areas, it left me a little underwhelmed by the end. First off, the cast is fantastic — Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy have great chemistry, and they really sell the romance and tension. Scott Derrickson knows how to craft atmosphere, and the first two acts really nail that mysterious, slow-burn thriller vibe. The setup of two operatives on opposing sides of a dangerous gorge is intriguing, and there are some genuinely effective jump scares. But then the third act hits, and it kind of falls apart. It shifts gears from a mysterious, atmospheric thriller into a generic action movie — explosions, shootouts, and all. The lore behind the creatures felt a bit thin and predictable; I kept hoping for some deeper twist or reveal that never came. The pacing was also all over the place — it starts strong but starts to drag in the middle before rushing through the climax. Honestly, the whole time I kept thinking this would make an amazing video game — the setting, the tension, the action — but as a movie, it just doesn't quite stick the landing. Still, worth a watch for the cast and early tension.

The Gorge boasts a creative premise, elevated by the undeniable chemistry between Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy. Strong practical effects and solid action keep things engaging, though the film loses steam in the back half once the mystery unravels—but it’s still a solid choice for a night in

What in the Baggins is this? The plot: two exceptionally good looking people, both world-class snipers (of course), she in sexy clothes (of course), are hired to guard a mysterious gorge. Proficient in every weapon known to man, the handsome duo fall in long-distance love, fight off saber-wielding Evil Ent/White Walkers riding dead horses in a blasted out Mirkwood Forest replete with tree spiders – when not busy, the Ents spawn in slimy cocoons. Our heroes beat off an army of these devil creatures, blow stuff up, topple down waterfalls and hoist themselves up perpendicular cliffs with nary a scratch. At some point the heroes happen upon a deserted-for-decades bio-chemical warfare lab whereupon they become bio-chemical computer experts with know-how to operate every machine since the Cold War. Lo and behold – the dastardly plan is revealed: it’s a plot to breed super soldiers lead by The Dark Corporation. A bit more fighting goes on; they blow up The Gorge and the Dark CEO, nevertheless they’re fine, find time to say “I love you” and meet up in a Jason Bourne Mykonos finale somewhere on the coast of France.

Some love stories unfold in candlelit rooms, against the backdrop of sunsets or in the midst of grand orchestras. But The Gorge dares to ask—what if love is born in the heart of darkness? What if romance isn’t a fleeting whisper but a burning light in an abyss so deep it swallows everything? Scott Derrickson’s The Gorge is marketed as a sci-fi action thriller with horror elements, but at its core, it is a story about connection, about two souls colliding in a place where neither should have ever met. Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy play two elite snipers stationed on opposite sides of a vast, ominous chasm, each tasked with an assignment that quickly becomes something much more profound. The gorge itself—a hollow, endless void—becomes a metaphor for both separation and destiny. From the moment the protagonists first interact, the tension is palpable. At first, it’s the natural wariness of two professionals sizing each other up, trying to determine if they are friend or foe. But as the film progresses, something unexpected happens: warmth begins to creep in. The film cleverly uses its sci-fi horror elements not just for spectacle but as a way to push these two closer together. In many ways, their growing affection is more thrilling than the gunfights or supernatural elements lurking beneath the surface. There is something undeniably intoxicating about the way their relationship unfolds—hesitant at first, then urgent and undeniable. The danger surrounding them doesn’t just heighten the stakes; it amplifies every glance, every whispered conversation over the radio, every shared silence. The gorge itself is a stunning paradox. It is, by all definitions, a lifeless place. Cold, dark, and vast, it represents separation, danger, and death. But within that void, something extraordinary happens—love flourishes. The film plays with this contrast beautifully, turning what should be a symbol of despair into one of fate. Without the gorge, these two would have remained strangers, caught up in their own separate missions. The very thing that threatens to consume them is also what allows them to truly see each other. There’s a poetic irony in that, one that elevates the film beyond just another sci-fi thriller. The Gorge isn’t just about surviving the abyss—it’s about proving that even in the bleakest circumstances, love can take root and thrive. Perhaps the most heartbreaking aspect of The Gorge is the idea that its two leads are, in the grand scheme of things, expendable. They are soldiers, trained professionals, people whose lives are not meant to be written in history books. And yet, within this hidden war, within this forgotten battlefield, their love story becomes something monumental. This is what makes The Gorge stand out. It doesn’t offer a fairytale romance. It doesn’t promise a happy ending. Instead, it delivers something raw, something urgent—love that exists because it has to, because it is the only thing that makes the struggle worthwhile. Teller and Taylor-Joy bring this to life with performances that are both restrained and deeply emotional, never overplaying the romance but letting it simmer beneath every scene. Is The Gorge a perfect film? No. Some will find its sci-fi elements overwhelming, others may wish the romance had been given even more room to breathe. But for those who see past the gunfire, past the horror, past the darkness, there is something undeniably powerful at its heart. This is not just a film about survival—it is a film about meaning. About how, sometimes, love is not found in grand gestures or ideal circumstances. Sometimes, love is forged in the most unexpected places. Sometimes, love is the flickering light in the deepest abyss. And that? That’s the kind of story that stays with you.

Watching the trailer for The Gorge I gathered that it would be a unique movie as it tries to blend monster horror, romance, and action-adventure—a combination created to offer a light, escapist experience after a long day. The film's original premise sets it apart as a potential background watch during a casual meal or a relaxed evening, daring to defy traditional genre boundaries. At first glance, the film’s bold ambition is evident. It shifts gears abruptly—from quirky, rom-com moments to bursts of action—mirroring the unpredictability of its narrative. There are fleeting hints of innovative storytelling, it feels a bit like Annihilation and When Harry Met Sally. However, these transitions often feel more like disjointed experiments than a cohesive blend of genres. As the narrative unfolds, several shortcomings emerge. The film leans on outdated clichés—such as contrived military salutes and other hackneyed moments—that sap its credibility. Early scenes border on cheesiness, undermining the film’s intended tone and leaving the horror elements underdeveloped. The chemistry between the leads occasionally shines through, it is often overshadowed by a predictable storyline and mechanical performances. Notably, Anya Taylor-Joy, whose involvement initially raised high expectations, seems to be navigating familiar territory rather than delivering the nuanced depth that I had hoped for Moreover, the dialogue frequently falls flat, and the film’s heavy reliance on CGI and exaggerated sound effects creates a dissonance, particularly during extended nighttime visuals that leave the audience disoriented. Despite high production values and a few standout moments, the film’s rushed ending and uneven script ultimately prevent it from reaching its full potential. The Gorge for me is neither a complete triumph nor an outright failure. It offers enough entertainment to serve as a fun, if imperfect, diversion—ideal for when you’re ready to switch off your analytical brain on a rainy afternoon. However, for something that started off strong and combined the unique genres, a more cohesive narrative, better script, as well as the right balance of CGI, this could have been a great film. A good exercise in showcasing restraint rather than over doing it all. A fun, nothing too serious flick to chuck on on a rainy day 6/10

The whiplash-inducing manner in which this film jumps from genre to genre would almost require a health hazard warning. The fact that it still somehow holds together and works is testament to Scott Derrickson's sheer determination and slick direction, not to mention his effective, perhaps unashamedly brazen, wrangling of logic-defying genre movie tropes, of which there are many, that manage to make this viewer happy to overlook them but not before some serious eye-rolling. The film begins intriguingly as a high concept mystery thriller as Miles Teller's American ex-Marine Levi and Anya Taylor-Joy's Lithuanian assassin Drasa were recruited separately for their sniper skills to guard opposite sides of a huge mysterious gorge. Soon, some seriously long distance flirting develops into a full-on romantic interlude whilst we discover that sensitive Levi writes poetry and Drasa is grieving over her dying father. Thankfully before this turns into an outright weepy, Derrickson, who's known more for his horror movies and the first Doctor Strange, reverts back to what he does best as all hell breaks loose in Zach Dean's screenplay and we find out what's hidden in that gorge is an Upside Down version of Oppenheimer with a bit of Sleepy Hollow thrown in for good measure. One of those films that doesn't really make any sense if you start scrutinizing the details (Do they have regular Amazon delivery of steaks and champagne?) but if you can go with the flow, it's an enjoyably silly and reasonably well made film, where everybody involved is aware that they are better than the material they're given, yet still give it their all to try to make it work. Essentially a B-movie with a A-list cast and budget and for a direct-to-streamer movie, it's comparatively better than a lot of the nonsense we've had before.

The Gorge (2025) is a movie that gets a lot of things right, blending action, romance, and a bit of suspense into a well-paced story. The plot is simple yet clever, unfolding naturally without unnecessary complexity. It keeps things engaging with steady character development, making you feel connected to the leads as their situation evolves. While some critics seem to take the romance out of context, it actually makes perfect sense within the story. It’s not just there for the sake of it but develops realistically based on their circumstances. Sure, there are some plot holes, but unless you're watching just to nitpick, they don’t take away from the experience. Visually, the movie stands out with dramatic lighting and smart camera work that keeps you immersed. Even daytime scenes carry a certain mood that adds to the film’s atmosphere. The cinematography is well thought out, with the right angles capturing the emotional depth of the characters while also making the action sequences hit hard. Speaking of action, while there’s plenty of it, the movie does lean more into its emotional core rather than being a full-on action spectacle. The CGI is solid, blending in naturally without feeling overdone, and while some moments might remind you of other films, it never feels like a cheap copy. The performances are strong, with both leads carrying the entire movie effortlessly. Their chemistry feels real, and their dialogue doesn’t come off as forced or unnatural. The script is well executed, moving the story forward at the right pace without dragging things out. The music and sound design complement the film nicely, enhancing key moments without overpowering them. Overall, The Gorge has a high rewatch factor, the kind of movie you'd want to show a friend just to experience it again. If Apple gives it a sequel, there's a lot of potential to expand on what made this one work so well.

The first half hooks you in with some genuinely engaging moments—there’s a spark there that keeps you invested. But then it all unravels. The CGI is a letdown, looking more like a rough draft than a polished effect, which pulls you right out of the experience. The second half? Bland as unseasoned toast. The twists are telegraphed from a mile away, stripping away any chance of real suspense. For a movie billed as a suspense flick, it’s baffling how it manages to feel so flat and predictable. It’s like they forgot the suspense part entirely. Save your time—this one’s a gorge-ous misfire.
Someone saw Annihilation and decided to create a story around the twig people in the Shimmer. Plus add in snipers for hire and a love story. Not worth the time.

It was definitely an interesting movie I really liked it and it was a romantic movie to watch with ur loved one intense and romance watched it three times that’s how much I liked it one of my favorite movies now

A very entertaining film, it mixes romance with great chemistry between the characters, action, horror and mystery very well developed throughout the film, without underestimating the intelligence of the viewer. The protagonists are well developed within the proposal, charismatic and Anna Taylor Joy and Milles Teller are great. First-rate fun, I highly recommend it, I loved it!

A mish mash of genres cute romantic comedy, overtone of Mr and Mrs Smith, with a bit of Second World War spy intrigue and a dash of ice warriors left over costumes from Game of Thrones. On the whole, the characters were likeable but not believable, great photographic scenes and for action fans this will be good! Lots of explosions and escapades. I dont regret watching it but they could have done so much more with this - the bones of a great story but got steamrolled by Hollywood machine.

Definitely worth the watch. The love story arch is not a simple trope as many reviews would suggest. There is enough action to keep you entertained in a movie about protagonists that have a military background, as well simple comedy to give some laughs in the "slow" moments. An interesting story that is somehow fresh in 2025. If there is any interest in anything firearm related they got most everything right from the guns on the wall following the eras mentioned in the film to how the actors handle them. Some things are a little exaggerated but overall the gun play is better than a lot of hollywood flicks. biggest gripe...grenade launchers have an arming distance of more than 12 feet.

Though I don’t consider myself a professional movie reviewer, I found myself reflecting critically on The Gorge. The film seemed to struggle with authenticity; many of its moments felt contrived rather than organic. While there were action scenes that aimed to thrill, they ultimately fell short due to a lackluster script that hindered any real emotional engagement. The clichéd boy-meets-girl narrative, a trope that many viewers have seen countless times before, unfortunately, felt tired and uninspired. Additionally, for those with military experience, the challenges faced regarding ammunition in the plot might resonate, but even that subplot didn’t elevate the overall viewing experience. All things considered, I would rate this film a modest 2.5 stars out of 5.

I am a huge fan of the 3 main actors in this movie from Sigourney Weaver to Miles Teller and Anya Joy-Taylor I have repeatedly found some of my favorite films and series, and the Gorge is a story type that suits them all well with compelling visuals and veteran acting skill that create a world of stunning military dramatics and a love story in a hopeless place all while trying to find a way to honor duty and protect the world and still honor the life they never envisioned for themselves. A beautiful story in the end, though wrought with many dilemmas I was satisfied with the movie albeit the beginning was a bit slower than I'd hoped.
It was an ok movie...something to watch if you want to pass time and there aren't any good ones available for viewing. The ending felt forced or should I say, felt incomplete.
Not really. Predictable and boring.

Just a poor movie. You get shocked awake once in a while from a loud bang, but it has no ability to keep your attention. Everything is in the dark, so it is also difficult to see. The added sounds and electronic sound is just a cheap side effect meant to sound Tense.

The Gorge actually delivers. They could’ve taken the easy way out and not made the gorge anything exciting but they didn’t. Beautiful visuals, ok comedic elements, and lots of action.

Filme: Entre Montanhas Assistido: 25-2-25 Elenco: @miles.teller @nayataylorjoy @sigourneyweaver.hun @sopedirisu Modelo: #fantasia #ação #romance Duração: 2h 7m Ano: 2025 Minha opinião: Ver um filme com Teller e Taylor Joy os dois atores em destaque em Hollywood, não poderia perder um filme deles. Não sei se este filme é o melhor para extrair deles suas performance. Mas a performance de Taylor em ação foi boa. O filme mistura o estilo de Stranger Things, existe um outro mundo em uma fenda, desde do fim da 2ª Guerra. Onde uma arma química fundia o DNA humano com outros como de plantas e animais. KKKkkkk mas é isso mesmo, e que vivem desde aquela época de 40. E assim são colocados vigilantes do lado ocidental e oriente (EUA e Russia) e a cada 1 ano são trocados os vigilantes. E agora pelo lado americano Levi (Teller) e Drasa pelo lado russo (Taylor-Joy). Os motivos para a estória do filme acho esdruxelas, mas da para curtir o ínicio do romance dos 2, até o momento que Levi cai e Drasa vai atrás para salva-lo. E onde encontram seres mutantes que já estão lá a quase 80 anos. E este mundo que eles estão é onde lembra Stranger Things. E lá eles descobrem o laboratório e um arsenal de armas. E para salvar o mundo e da Bartholomew (Signorney) eles armam um plano para destruir tudo e salvar o Mundo. A química entre Taylor e Teller foi boa. Roteiro e enredo poderia ser muito melhor. A estória que motiva o filme é uma piada. Mas a atuação dos 2 salva. Vale apena assistir? sim Nota: 7 por causa de Teller e Taylor Joy.
I liked it. Sure, it's a bit silly, and the situation is both outlandish and predictable, but so what? It's escapist stuff, and sometimes we need to sit back and let it wash over us.
A fantastic film full of action and surprises. Had me on the edge of my seat
A beautiful, memorable film. I recommend everyone even if you do not like movies.

The Gorge is a quite predictable, but fairly enjoyable movie with great lighting and colour grading. The characters are generic, not layered, but their interactions are interesting to watch. I liked both of them, but they didn't grow and didn't have anything to be intrigued by, only their relationship and the actors's chemistry. The concept is cool, but the story is predictable. The dialogues are sometimes just so unrealistic. The cinematography is good. It's lighting and colour grading is very similar to Silo's, which I love. The editing is generic and the beginning of the movie is too long. The score is unique, but it wasn't great, because I knew the ending of dramatic moments, because the music told me what would happen. For example I knew when he would or would not fall into the gorge. The acting is also just okay even though the casting os good and the actors' chemistry keeps the movie going. The Gorge is neither original nor well-crafted, but it's still an enjoyable ride.
I loved it! I wasn't bored at all. The story kept me locked in!
I found it to be a nice surprise.

A just-okay attempt at the sci-fi/fantasy genre. With lead actors so well known, one may think The Gorge would be a sure-fire hit, but the film fumbles when trying to find its footing. The world building is blurry at best, and though the premise is promising, the concept of the gorge itself lacks serious definition. What could have been an exciting and riveting action movie muddies the waters by introducing a romance plot a quarter of the way through the film. The chemistry between the lead actors feels forced or feigned, and the believability of their romantic connection seems to be far-fetched. An entertaining but not particularly smart movie.
Perfectly fine streaming movie.
O filme foi um boa surpresa. Envolve ação, ficção e romance com um bom cenário e uma boa história. Diversão garantida.
Was a very enjoyable experience. Took me back to the days where movies were about the story not the action. I would say it's a must watch and you won't regret it.

I really enjoyed watching them explore and fight their way through the Gorge and just the overall looks of it. It also had a nice ending I did not expect. 5/5!

a movie with little words but a grate story.

Entertaining, but the special effects are poor, the leads were poorly cast (both need to mix-in some physical training), the screenwriting is terrible, and some of the scenes are laughable. And for goodness sake, at least figure out if a former Marine civilian is supposed to salute someone indoors. It's a small thing, but just inexcusably sloppy like a lot of the film. And by the way, the AI bots giving this 4 or 5 stars and referencing the "combination of 3 genres" or variations of that review are pretty obvious. Ignore those.

This movie is slow to start and fast to finish. Anya Taylor-Joy and Miles Teller make the most of what they're given. Their charisma goes a long way to make their characters feel more endearing, but any substance beyond that gets lost in overly expository dialogue, choppy action sequences, and an apparent lack of budget for lights on set.

It was an unexpectedly good watch, usually, I find those types of movies boring and unfunny it was the opposite with that movie I was kept at the edge of my seat with good humor and the movie was at times emotional and not the forced type.

I really enjoyed this movie. The overall plot was very interesting to me. I liked watching the dynamic between the two characters as they get to know each other day after day, close enough to see each other, but far enough apart that they can’t have an intimate conversation or touch one another. When they finally do get a chance to be close, everything goes to hell and we learn more and more about the secrets that the gorge holds. The “evil, international private company/paramilitary group” has been done to death but I feel like there’s always a way to bring a dash of something new and exciting to it and The Gorge did this beautifully in my opinion. It grabbed my attention and held it throughout the film. The trailer didn’t nearly do it justice, as I wasn’t expecting a lot of the movie from the trailer, but I was more than pleasantly surprised.

The film's first half successfully builds tension and intrigue, drawing viewers into the enigmatic setting and the protagonists' developing relationship. However, as the narrative progresses, it succumbs to conventional tropes, leading to a predictable and somewhat underwhelming conclusion. Despite the strong performances and initial promise, the latter part of the film feels rushed and lacks the depth anticipated from its outset. In summary, while "The Gorge" offers a captivating start with commendable acting and a unique blend of genres, it ultimately falls short in delivering a satisfying and original ending. The film is worth a watch for its strengths, but there's a lingering sense that it could have achieved more.

A cross genre sci-fi/ romance/ fantasy /action /horror movie. Yes that description is actually correct but somehow this mashup works sufficiently due to the quality of the lead actors even if the attempt at originality is not fully realised. You have elements of Alien (appropriate casting for Sigourney), some similarities to the terrible Pratt / Lawrence hook up in Passengers and a (sort of) mutant story thrown in for good measure. Visually it's pretty decent and certainly worth a view even if you could drive a rather large truck through some of the plotline threads. Look out for the tilts to previous roles played by Miles and Anya, you get a bit of Whiplash and The Queen's Gambit.
Fun, entertaining, endearing!
Love films like this. It was like an action adventure version of the horror movie the mist. Totally entertained the entire time and exactly what I needed on a Sunday night

Not especially intelligent or original but entertaining as hell! Great romance combined with horror and bizarre landscapes that reminded me of Annihilation. Also loved the music during end credit texts... It was hypnotizing and great closure for the experience.
I had no expectations and it became a new favourite. A bit of everything mixed perfectly.
If you're bored, stream this movie and you'll forget your boredom, because it's a good mix of horror, sci-fi and action with a bit of romance. Not a great film, but good entertainment.

What if Annihilation was a romance with a bunch of the second half of Aliens thrown in? That's what I kept thinking as I watched recent paramours guy and girl snipers descend into the cloudy mists of The Gorge. There's an awful lot of convenient things here like giant pads of paper that make communicating across the gorge a piece of cake, or an easy-to-find movie that explains exactly the mystery of the Annihilation-esque creatures. There's also too many plot holes such as how there's been a (spoiler time) ongoing chemical leak for like 80 years that affects all living things and not only has the gas not gotten out at all (not through wind or water) no mutant birds, bats, bugs, snakes, squirrels, or whatever have escaped. Also one of our heroes is dragged off only to be held captive by one creature who is suddenly in no hurry to kill her. The acting from Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy keep this film watchable even if the long-distance romance of the first third was a bit schlocky. Sigourney Weaver is back in another of her antagonist roles. Ultimately I can't say I regretted watching The Gorge, but I wouldn't have missed much if I hadn't.

I still think the talents of Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy are enough to carry the movie, particularly their chemistry when it comes to romance. I also thought the premise was neat and the visuals in the movie were enjoyable. Overall, this movie is okay but it does feel like it had the potential to be better, but still will surely please multiple genre fans.

Decent action scenes and interesting story with its clearly divided chapters that each served their own purpose. I liked the dark atmosphere of the Gorge lit with streaks of vivid color. But, a few things: (1) Levi's adventure from the dropoff point to the West Tower felt extremely rushed and cut up as they squeezed all of that into like 20 seconds; I get they were probably trying to shorten the film but it was very noticeable. (2) The dynamic between the leads was too cliche and sentimental. (3) Most of the Gorge tree human hybrids belong better on the set of Power Rangers; too PG and costume-like. P.S. I got the brief nods to Anya's chess mini series (The Queen's Gambit) and Miles' drum film (Whiplash), which I've also seen. Those productions were also better in most ways, although I did mostly enjoy this ride.

A unique main plot line captivates with convincing on screen chemistry from its co-stars which makes for an enjoyable watch. Areas of the plot left with little to no explanation and a tendency to fall into the pitfalls of predictability. On the whole a good watch from two very talented actors.

It's good, really good. I liked it a lot. It's not the typical love story. It's exciting and scary and no boring spaces between the movie. It's like Resident Evil with romance and more realistic. Hope to get a part 2.

(Reviews you can understand and trust) An excellent movie for Saturday night viewing, both entertaining and endearing. It’s certainly better than most multiplex fare these days, that’s for certain. The leads are believable and have an under the radar vibe that creates the required bond for their relationship … and for us to care when things inevitably go bonkers. Their initial communication across the expanse is clever, but what sets that portion of the movie apart is the writing (literally), which will invoke at least a few “awe’s,” as in, “how cute!” The Sci-fi is acceptable (and obligatory), as is the story, but it has its moments. The scenes within the church, lab, and final escape attempt are top notch. Go ahead and gorge on The Gorge. You’ll exit the couch more than satisfied.

I liked the premise but the time line should have been set prior to drone technology. Trying to suspend my disbelief that the threat posed was actually a threat is difficult, being aware of the technology available. Once the secret is revealed the whole import for the main actors roles feels unnecessary. Loved the concept. Sad about the lack of attention paid to plausibility.

This was a solid & entertaining movie. I could see someone calling the shift in tone jolting but it was refreshing and really highlighted the shock our protagonists felt. The movie was very original & I appreciated the good story that has a beginning, middle & end with no loose ends or ambiguity. The ability to tell an original story without leaving one guessing in order to leave the door open for sequels is a lost art and this movie delivered.

Up to about an hour into this movie I thought it was going to be one of the best movies id ever seen. However the tension is completely broken after the mystery of gorge is revealed about halfway through. It was still really good - but it was almost absolutely excellent.

A fresh, unique break from the recycled plots that Hollywood has been churning out recently. A love story with a heavy sci-fi element is fun, exciting and absolutely watchable. The chemistry between Anya Taylor Joy and Miles Teller is real, palpable, and sweet. I was immersed the entire time, investing in these characters and seeing them have a positive outcome. Fantastic fun, start to finish.

ORIGINAL CONCEPT SCENARIO, ENJOYABLE DUO BUT SOME OVER THE TOP SCENES : "The Gorge" is a wild, over-the-top ride that never fails to entertain, largely thanks to its charismatic duo. The film boasts an original concept, blending intense sci-fi with a dash of horror, and at times, it evokes the tense atmosphere of World War Z alongside the eerie vibes of Stranger Things(I had a few jump scares). While the movie pushes its limits with extravagant moments, it still manages to captivate with its inventive narrative and engaging performances, earning a solid 7/10. Note that its mature themes and intense content make it better suited for viewers aged 16 and older rather than a younger audience(not -10 years old like it's suggested at the start of the movie).

Best si-fi romance I’ve seen in years. Finally a film where the main characters were not competing against each other but actually worked together. The story was quite simple but the chemistry was off the charts, you could tell how much they enjoyed their time together, didn’t feel forced at all. You know girls can be strong, capable and independent without putting others down. And the male lead, Levi? Chef’s kiss, caring, respectful but still muscular as well, if I was Drasa, I would totally fall for him too! 10/10 recommend people who love this genre of films!

Best sci fi, action, romance flick I've seen in years. The only thing I hate about this movie is I can't see it again for the first time. Lot's of snobs giving it 2 or 3 stars. My wife would give this film a 0.1 star. But she hates movies like this. I happen to love this movie. People who hate movies like this shouldn't be reviewing them.

This movie was super fun to see, it was a mix of warfare, love and sci-fi! There was never a dull moment, both actors are amazing and played the part perfectly! The plot twist as well and the governmental history behind it! Loved it.

Enjoyable action movie with a plot that holds water.
Anya Taylor-Joy es de las mejor de la película igual que siempre, muy interesante toda la película y muy buen plot twist. Recomendada.

I just watched The Gorge (2025), and wow—what a ride! It’s got everything: action, romance, and just the right amount of mind-bending twists to keep you hooked. Miles Teller and Anya Taylor-Joy have amazing chemistry, and their performances really pull you in. The story keeps you guessing, and the visuals are stunning. It’s the kind of movie that sticks with you after the credits roll. Definitely worth watching!

Great movie! Keeps you on your feet. Compelling plot. Miles Teller and ATJ had great on-screen chemistry. Their characters communicate relatable emotions despite unrelatable circumstances. The combination of mystery, romance, and suspense make this movie a must watch.
Enjoyable movie with an interesting plot.

I admit I’m a bit of an elitist. I hate formulaic action movies, super-hero movies, thrillers and the like. I want movies to have plots that make sense; for an original path to be taken; for human emotions to be explored in some meaningful way. This movie had none of that. Yet somehow I kinda enjoyed it. If you’re just looking for a movie to help pass by a couple of hours, this is a decent way to do it.
Great movie! Miles Taylor & Anya taylor-joy had great chemistry together. There were a few plot convinces but other than that, fantastic movie

I loved it. It had all the fun beats of an action thriller, plus a romance that felt genuine. The cinematography was better than most, and some shots were quite well done in my opinion. Acting and dialog was solid throughout. The plot was outlandish, but semi-plausible. Much more believable than most movies that everyone "gives a pass" to. Go into it blind, and just enjoy it for what it is, not what you expect or want it to be, and you'll have fun. I see the critics are rating it lower than the public. Critics simply don't have the zeitgeist on cinema culture all the time.
Brilliant !! Beautiful acting. Up-close horrors of real-life quadcopters and bio-weapons research. A sci-fi film befitting the world today.
Loved the action and the chemistry between ATJ and Miles Teller. Great story and fun movie overall.

The combination between horror and romance balanced with almost perfection. Anya Taylor Joy puts on yet another great acting performance. And I never thought I’d see miles teller with a full beard. However, I loved what they did with the chess bit, it was definitely a queens gambit reference.

Going into this sci-fi romance action movie I said to my wife, “I am so excited, this has the making of everything that is Edge of Tomorrow - new unique sci-fi concept, action, romance, and some huge threat that must be stopped by the pair to save humankind”. While The Gorge isn’t as good as Edge, I still loved it. I saw a critic say that it’s basically Romeo & Juliet mixed with The Last of Us mixed with Annihilation, and that’s a great way to describe it. If you haven’t seen any of those, then I’d basically say it’s just a great popcorn date night flick that will appeal to fans of just about any genre.

The idea of two people on opposite sides watching over a gorge so monsters can not come out is a fun concept. For the most part, the film delivers on the idea while having an enjoyable romance on top. Miles Teller and Anna Taylor Joy have incredible chemistry and I brought the build-up of their relationship. It has a fun tension and romantic-filled first act with an excellent action video-game-like second act. Unfortunately, the film is let down a bit by a dull and overly convenient final act. Still, this is a solid two-hour popcorn flick that entertains the audience.

While the plot can be fairly predictable, it doesn't take away from the fun of the film. You aren't going to be shocked by any twists or reveals, but the acting is great and the story is fun. The first introduction to the antagonists within the Gorge is one of the most fun and suspenseful actions scenes I've seen on film in a while. I was initially concerned the story would drag with the main characters being separated and unable to communicate other than through messages viewed through binoculars; but the pace was solid and it never felt slow, even on a rewatch after I knew what was going to happen.

The first hour had one of the most compelling storylines ever. The loneliness, haunted pasts, two elite snipers separated by duty, and a hellish mystery. It had immense potential, but there you go. Instead of a work of art, we get more Hollywood BS. The relationship between the two is underdeveloped. Instead of two well-written characters with real depth, after the first hour of the movie, they turn into two clique action superheroes. As for the Gorge, the best part about a mystery is... THE MYSTERY. But if you really must resolve the mystery... really? The trees from Narnia? That was the best thing writers could come up with...?

I enjoyed the premise of this big budget flick but I can’t help thinking this was a huge missed opportunity to make a much more meaningful movie. Aside from the basic premise of two towers protecting a dangerous and mysterious gorge, there are no new ideas here. The characters and plot are so predictable, this movie almost feels nostalgic of the kind of massive budget Hollywood filmmaking of the Marvel era. Why did Apple greenlight this movie when they could have made 10 better, more thoughtful for the same money? Go figure.

Great cast, though there's a few plot holes, I had a lot of fun watching this. Effects are really awesome too. In my personal opinion, there's not a single moment in the movie where you go "Well this is boring."

Anya Taylor-Joy and Miles Teller are extremely watchable, thus the 1.5 stars. But if I were either of them, I would fire my agent. The pastiche of various movie genres really doesn't work. Nor do the horror bits stolen from The Last of Us, Peter Jackson's King Kong, etc. I don't think there's one original idea in this movie.

There's a little bit of everything in The Gorge - and it all works! It's fitting that it was released on Valentine's Day, as it's first and foremost a romance. Having said that, it's also a thriller, with elements of sci-fi, conspiracy, horror, and more. If that sounds a bit scattered, for me and my wife it was just the right mix. There was always something going on and the interaction between the two leads made for a totally enjoyable experience. Honestly, I think Apple TV+ could have released The Gorge in the theatres and it would have done pretty well, but they haven't had much luck selling their feature films to mass audiences. That's fine with me, as the occasional movie just adds to the overall value of our Apple subscription, which is worth every penny. All around, The Gorge is a thoroughly enjoyable movie and a perfect date-night choice.

I don't have the energy nor the mood to try to do it all again, so i'll just leave the main argument, The Gorge is a professionally made movie with actors whom we know to be very good (from different movies), but which is bad anyway. Oh, and important thing, i contracted two actors, young guy and a woman, kinda famous, so there absolutely have to be man and a woman. They have a dangerous job, at first they just kinda look at each other, then they get together later, make it an achievement. Something like that, oh and put in some stuff for nerds - like chess, painting pictures, composing opera, some nerdy stuff like that, people sometimes confuse props evoking certain stuff for the stuff itself. Oki, thx!"

The Gorge – A Perfectly Balanced Thrill Ride Just finished watching The Gorge, and honestly, it hit all the right marks. The story was tight, just enough depth without overcomplicating itself. What stood out the most was how the romance between the two snipers wasn’t just a subplot but the beating heart of the film. It wove itself seamlessly into the action, the tension, and every moment of suspense. Anya Taylor-Joy? Phenomenal, as always. There’s something about her performances that makes every character feel alive. She doesn’t just play a role, she becomes it. And Miles Teller? Equally impressive. Although his performance in Whiplash will always take some beating. He brought the right balance of grit and vulnerability, making the chemistry between them feel raw and believable. The action? Sharp. Well-paced. Not too over-the-top for film genres like this. never lacking. Just the right amount of everything really, suspense, emotion, and intensity. It’s rare for a film to walk that line so well, but The Gorge nailed it. Easily one of the better films I’ve seen in a while. Give it a watch, switch off and enjoy the ride.

The Gorge promised a lot but didn’t quite deliver. The initial appeal—whether it was the stunning views, the premise, or the hype—quickly faded once you got past the surface. It’s not a total wash; there are flashes of brilliance (the scenery was decent, or maybe a couple of scenes hit the mark), but they’re buried under a slog of mediocrity. Too much felt underdeveloped or overhyped, leaving me wishing for more substance. It’s not the worst I’ve encountered, but it’s far from memorable. Two stars for effort and potential that just didn’t pan out.
